capTable.title: Cap Table
capTable.description: A capitalisation (cap) table is a record of all the shareholders in a company, showing who owns what percentage. It tracks shares issued, ownership percentages, and the value of equity at different rounds.

valuation.title: Company Valuation
valuation.description: The estimated total worth of the company. For startups, this is typically determined during funding rounds based on investor negotiations, comparable companies, or financial projections.

sharePrice.title: Share Price
sharePrice.description: The current value of a single share, calculated by dividing the company valuation by the total number of shares issued (or fully diluted shares).

fullyDiluted.title: Fully Diluted Shares
fullyDiluted.description: The total number of shares that would exist if all convertible securities (options, convertible notes, SAFEs, warrants) were converted into ordinary shares. This gives a more complete picture of ownership.

issuedShares.title: Issued Shares
issuedShares.description: The actual number of shares that have been formally issued to shareholders. This excludes options or convertibles that haven't been exercised yet.

authorizedShares.title: Authorised Shares
authorizedShares.description: The maximum number of shares the company is allowed to issue as specified in its constitution. This sets an upper limit on total shares that can be created.

investorType.title: Investor Type
investorType.description: Categories of investors: Founders (original creators), Angels (high-net-worth individuals), VCs (venture capital firms), Employees (staff with equity), and Strategic investors (corporations investing for strategic reasons).

ownership.title: Ownership Percentage
ownership.description: The proportion of the company owned by a shareholder, calculated as their shares divided by total shares. This determines voting power and share of any exit proceeds.

proRataRights.title: Pro-Rata Rights
proRataRights.description: The contractual right for an existing investor to participate in future funding rounds to maintain their ownership percentage. Without this, their stake would be diluted.

totalInvested.title: Total Invested
totalInvested.description: The total amount of money an investor has contributed to the company in exchange for shares across all funding rounds.

currentShares.title: Current Shares
currentShares.description: The number of shares currently held by an investor, accounting for any sales, transfers, or exits they may have made.

exitedInvestor.title: Exited Investor
exitedInvestor.description: An investor who has sold all their shares, either through a secondary sale to another investor, a company buyback, or an exit event like an acquisition.

fundingRound.title: Funding Round
fundingRound.description: A discrete event where the company raises capital from investors in exchange for equity. Common rounds include Seed, Series A, Series B, etc.

preMoneyValuation.title: Pre-Money Valuation
preMoneyValuation.description: The company's valuation immediately before a new investment. Used with the investment amount to calculate how many shares new investors receive.

postMoneyValuation.title: Post-Money Valuation
postMoneyValuation.description: The company's valuation immediately after investment. Calculated as Pre-Money Valuation + Investment Amount.

amountRaised.title: Amount Raised
amountRaised.description: The total capital received from investors in a funding round in exchange for newly issued shares.

roundType.title: Round Type
roundType.description: Seed: Early-stage funding for product development. Series A/B/C: Growth-stage funding rounds. Bridge: Short-term funding between rounds. Pre-Seed: Very early, often from founders/friends.

leadInvestor.title: Lead Investor
leadInvestor.description: The investor who negotiates terms and typically invests the largest amount in a round. They often set the valuation and take a board seat.

pricePerShare.title: Price Per Share
pricePerShare.description: The amount paid for each share in a funding round. Calculated as Pre-Money Valuation รท Pre-Money Shares.

shareClass.title: Share Class
shareClass.description: Different categories of shares with different rights. Ordinary shares are standard. Preference shares may have liquidation preferences, dividends, or other special rights.

ordinary.title: Ordinary Shares
ordinary.description: Standard shares that represent basic ownership with voting rights and rights to dividends. Most common type for founders and employees.

preference.title: Preference Shares
preference.description: Shares with special rights, typically held by investors. Often include liquidation preference (get paid first in exit) and may have anti-dilution protection.

option.title: Options
option.description: The right (but not obligation) to purchase shares at a set price (strike/exercise price) in the future. Common for employee compensation. Must be exercised to become actual shares.

performanceRights.title: Performance Rights
performanceRights.description: A right to receive shares upon meeting performance conditions, with no exercise price required. Common in Australia for employee incentives under ESS rules.

liquidationPreference.title: Liquidation Preference
liquidationPreference.description: The right for preference shareholders to receive their investment back (often with a multiple) before ordinary shareholders receive anything in an exit or liquidation.

transactionType.title: Transaction Type
transactionType.description: The nature of a share movement: Issue (new shares created), Transfer (existing shares change hands), Exercise (option converted to shares), or Sale (shares sold).

issue.title: Share Issue
issue.description: The creation of new shares, increasing total shares outstanding. Occurs during funding rounds or when options/convertibles are exercised.

transfer.title: Share Transfer
transfer.description: When existing shares change ownership between parties. No new shares are created, so total shares remain the same.

exercise.title: Option Exercise
exercise.description: When an option holder converts their options into actual shares by paying the exercise/strike price. Creates new shares.

exercisePrice.title: Exercise/Strike Price
exercisePrice.description: The price an option holder must pay to convert each option into a share. Usually set at fair market value when the option was granted.

buyback.title: Share Buyback
buyback.description: When the company purchases its own shares from shareholders, reducing total shares outstanding. Often used for departing employees or capital returns.

secondarySale.title: Secondary Sale
secondarySale.description: When an existing shareholder sells their shares to another investor (not the company). The company receives no proceeds; shares simply change hands.

reequitization.title: Re-equitization
reequitization.description: When existing employee options are cancelled and replaced with new options at a different (usually lower) strike price. Common after a down round.

vesting.title: Vesting
vesting.description: The process by which shares or options become fully owned by the recipient over time. Protects the company if the person leaves early.

cliff.title: Cliff Period
cliff.description: An initial period (commonly 12 months) during which no shares vest. If the person leaves before the cliff, they forfeit all unvested shares.

vestingPeriod.title: Vesting Period
vestingPeriod.description: The total time over which shares gradually become fully vested. Standard is 4 years, often with monthly or quarterly vesting after the cliff.

acceleration.title: Acceleration
acceleration.description: When vesting speeds up due to specific triggers. Single-trigger: vesting accelerates on acquisition. Double-trigger: requires acquisition plus termination.

timeBased.title: Time-Based Vesting
timeBased.description: Shares vest gradually over time, regardless of performance. The most common vesting type for employees.

milestoneBased.title: Milestone Vesting
milestoneBased.description: Shares vest upon achievement of specific goals (revenue targets, product launches, etc.) rather than just passage of time.

hoursBased.title: Hours-Based Vesting
hoursBased.description: Shares vest based on hours worked rather than calendar time. Common for part-time contractors or advisors.

hybridVesting.title: Hybrid Vesting
hybridVesting.description: Combines multiple vesting types (time, milestones, hours) with weighted percentages. Provides flexibility for complex arrangements.

reverseVesting.title: Reverse Vesting
reverseVesting.description: The recipient owns all shares immediately but they're subject to buyback by the company if they leave before vesting completes. Common for founders.

goodLeaver.title: Good Leaver
goodLeaver.description: Someone who leaves under favourable circumstances (retirement, redundancy, disability). May receive accelerated vesting or better buyback terms.

badLeaver.title: Bad Leaver
badLeaver.description: Someone who leaves under unfavourable circumstances (resignation, termination for cause). Usually forfeits unvested shares and may face clawback of vested shares.

lapsing.title: Lapsing / Forfeiture
lapsing.description: When unvested options or shares are cancelled because the holder has left the company or conditions weren't met. The shares are typically returned to the ESOP pool.

convertibleNote.title: Convertible Note
convertibleNote.description: A loan that converts into equity at a future funding round. Includes a principal amount, interest rate, and conversion terms (discount and/or cap).

safe.title: SAFE
safe.description: Simple Agreement for Future Equity. Like a convertible note but simpler - no interest, no maturity date. Converts at the next priced round.

valuationCap.title: Valuation Cap
valuationCap.description: The maximum valuation at which a convertible will convert into shares. Protects early investors if the company's valuation increases significantly.

discount.title: Conversion Discount
discount.description: A percentage discount on the share price that convertible holders receive when converting. Typically 15-25%. Rewards early investment risk.

maturityDate.title: Maturity Date
maturityDate.description: The date when a convertible note must either convert to equity or be repaid. Creates a deadline for the company to raise a qualifying round.

qualifyingRound.title: Qualifying Round
qualifyingRound.description: A funding round that meets certain criteria (usually minimum amount raised) and triggers automatic conversion of outstanding convertibles.

conversionShares.title: Estimated Conversion Shares
conversionShares.description: The approximate number of shares a convertible will convert into, based on current valuation and conversion terms. May change at actual conversion.

dilution.title: Dilution
dilution.description: The reduction in ownership percentage when new shares are issued. While percentage decreases, the value of shares may increase if the company's valuation grows.

antiDilution.title: Anti-Dilution Protection
antiDilution.description: Rights that protect investors from excessive dilution, especially in down rounds. May result in additional shares being issued to protected investors.

downRound.title: Down Round
downRound.description: A funding round at a lower valuation than the previous round. Can trigger anti-dilution provisions and may require employee option repricing.

proRataCalculation.title: Pro-Rata Investment
proRataCalculation.description: The amount an investor must invest in a new round to maintain their current ownership percentage. Calculated based on their current stake and round size.

esop.title: ESOP / Option Pool
esop.description: Employee Share Option Plan. A pool of shares reserved for employee equity compensation. Typically 10-20% of the company, created before funding rounds.

esopDilution.title: ESOP Dilution Method
esopDilution.description: How the ESOP pool size is calculated: Pre-Round (dilutes existing shareholders), Post-Round (dilutes new and existing), or Fixed (set number of shares).

allocated.title: Allocated Options
allocated.description: Options from the ESOP pool that have been granted to specific employees. These count toward the pool usage.

unallocated.title: Unallocated Pool
unallocated.description: The remaining options in the ESOP pool that haven't been granted yet. Available for future employee grants.

poolExpansion.title: Pool Expansion
poolExpansion.description: Increasing the ESOP pool size, often as part of a funding round. This dilutes all shareholders but provides more options for future employees.

essTax.title: ESS Tax Rules (Australia)
essTax.description: Employee Share Scheme tax rules in Australia. Determines when and how equity compensation is taxed. Includes concessional treatment for eligible startups.

startupConcession.title: ESS Startup Concession
startupConcession.description: An Australian tax concession for eligible startup employees. If conditions are met, tax is deferred until a later event (sale, 15 years, etc.).

division83A.title: Division 83A
division83A.description: The section of Australian tax law governing Employee Share Schemes. Determines taxing point, amount, and available deferrals for employee equity.

taxingPoint.title: Taxing Point
taxingPoint.description: The point at which employee equity becomes taxable. May be at grant, vesting, exercise, or sale depending on the ESS rules and elections made.

exitWaterfall.title: Exit Waterfall
exitWaterfall.description: How proceeds from a company exit (sale/IPO) flow to shareholders. Liquidation preferences are paid first, then remaining proceeds split by ownership.

dilutionCalculator.title: Dilution Calculator
dilutionCalculator.description: A tool to model how a new funding round affects existing shareholders' ownership percentages.

roundSimulator.title: Round Simulator
roundSimulator.description: Models a future funding round to preview ownership changes, including ESOP expansion impact.

participatingPreferred.title: Participating Preferred
participatingPreferred.description: Preference shares that receive their liquidation preference AND participate in remaining proceeds. More investor-friendly than non-participating.

nonParticipatingPreferred.title: Non-Participating Preferred
nonParticipatingPreferred.description: Preference shares that choose either their liquidation preference OR their pro-rata share of proceeds, whichever is higher.

companyName.title: Company Name
companyName.description: The legal name of the company as registered with ASIC.

investorName.title: Investor Name
investorName.description: The legal name of the shareholder or investing entity.

numberOfShares.title: Number of Shares
numberOfShares.description: The quantity of shares involved in this transaction or holding.

roundName.title: Round Name
roundName.description: A descriptive name for the funding round (e.g., 'Seed Round', 'Series A').

transactionDate.title: Transaction Date
transactionDate.description: The effective date when shares were issued, transferred, or cancelled.

vestingStartDate.title: Vesting Start Date
vestingStartDate.description: The date from which the vesting clock begins. Typically the employment start date or grant date.

cliffMonths.title: Cliff (Months)
cliffMonths.description: The number of months before any shares vest. Standard is 12 months for employees.

vestingMonths.title: Vesting Period (Months)
vestingMonths.description: Total months over which shares fully vest. Standard is 48 months (4 years).
